content.title: CMS Configuration
content.content:
The entry point of Sapphire CMS is a configuration file: `sapphire-cms.config.yaml`. This file should be created at the root of your project:

```
My-Project
├── sapphire-cms.config.yaml
```

Example configuration:

```yaml
# ./sapphire-cms.config.yaml

config:
  debug: true
  modules:
    cli:
      editor: gedit
    node:
      data-dir: ./sapphire-cms-data
      output-dir: ./src/app/generated/cms
    codegen:
      placeholder: true

layers:
  bootstrap: "@node"
  persistence: "@node"
```

## Configuration Structure

The configuration file is divided into two parts:

### 1. `config`

This section provides configuration for the CMS and all its modules.

> [!NOTE]  
> Module configuration is **module-specific**.
> Please refer to the module’s documentation to learn about accepted parameters.

Sapphire CMS supports interpolation of **environment variables**, so it's safe to store sensitive values such as tokens, keys, or passwords in your environment.

> [!NOTE]  
> The way environment variables are provided depends on the platform.
> Refer to your platform’s documentation for more details.

Here’s an example using the GitHub module with an environment variable:

```yaml
# ./sapphire-cms.config.yaml

config:
  modules:
    github:
      owner: sapphire-cms
      repo: sapphire-cms-docs
      branch: master
      personal-access-token: ${env.GITHUB_PERSONAL_ACCESS_TOKEN}
```

### 2. `layers`

This section defines which layers your CMS should use.

The `@` symbol is used to specify that a particular layer should be loaded from a module.

For example:

```yaml
bootstrap: "@node"
```

This tells Sapphire CMS to use the bootstrap layer provided by the module `@sapphire-cms/node`.
